plants.name: Helianthus annuus
plants.description: A tall annual plant known for its large, bright yellow flowers with a central brown disk. It thrives in temperate regions and is widely cultivated for its seeds and oil.
plants.location: Northern Hemisphere temperate regions, including North America and Europe
plants.funFact: Sunflowers exhibit heliotropism, where young flower heads follow the sun from east to west during the day.

plants.name: Rhododendron macrophyllum
plants.description: An evergreen shrub with large, leathery leaves and clusters of pink to lavender bell-shaped flowers. It is native to the Pacific Northwest and blooms in late summer to early fall.
plants.funFact: The Pacific Rhododendron is the state flower of Washington.

plants.name: Wattle (Acacia pycnantha)
plants.description: A shrub or small tree with bright golden-yellow, fluffy flower clusters. It is the national floral emblem of Australia and blooms as winter transitions to spring in the Southern Hemisphere, but in some regions, blooms can start as early as August and continue into September.
plants.funFact: The bright yellow flowers of the Golden Wattle were used by Aboriginal Australians as a source of food and medicine.

plants.name: Ipomoea purpurea
plants.description: A fast-growing climbing vine with trumpet-shaped flowers that open in the morning and close in the afternoon. It blooms profusely in late summer to early autumn in many temperate regions.
plants.location: Widely cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Morning Glories exhibit photoperiodism, blooming in response to day length, which makes them bloom in late summer and early fall.
